Toy or tool?

Classroom tool with clear expectations around their use, out of sight, simple and inexpensive.

Also, have them written into IEPs/support plans as 'provision' not 'reward.' Explicitly state that the 'tool' break is not to be removed as a consequence.. @sencochat https://t.co/cyvX0l23wR

@Becky_Austin12 @sencochat @ThriveApproach @Nic_Crossley1 ...and is pressure/movement activated. Just the tent/mat/lamp are a great start. There's a really good feature of velcro in every corner at the top on the inside. I'm looking at lighting up go around the top that oozes on and off...I'm going to try some off the shelf ones..

@Becky_Austin12 @sencochat @ThriveApproach @Nic_Crossley1 It is tricky isn't it. We have an actual sensory room attached to my classroom, so things can be mounted on the wall, plugs aren't an issue etc . Yet the tent was a different challenge. I think less is more - the key items are great. The fibre optic mat perfectly fits the tent.+

@Becky_Austin12 @sencochat @ThriveApproach @Nic_Crossley1 I need the tents to be really safe. They cost so much because I need no tripping hazard with the wires and no water incase the lamp gets knocked over. Hence the cost of the 3 really key items...

@Becky_Austin12 @sencochat @ThriveApproach @Nic_Crossley1 No worries. In fairness, I could have bought pretty much everything off the TTS website! I took a while thinking about it and investigating the key items. I had ¬£500 per tent. The tent, rug, lamp and blocks came to ¬£400 per tent. I wish I'd got more of the blocks. They're fab.
